ArticleContent_mck-c-article-content__share-tools__kWRRw"></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-animation-blur-in-400"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">Emotions can drive market behavior in a few short-lived situations. But fundamentals still rule.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Fbusiness%20functions%2Fstrategy%20and%20corporate%20finance%2Four%20insights%2Fdo%20fundamentalsor%20emotionsdrive%20the%20stock%20market%2Fdo%20fundamentalsor%20emotionsdrive%20the%20stock%20market.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="do-fundamentalsor emotionsdrive the stock market" data-layer-report-name="do-fundamentalsor emotionsdrive the stock market>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (PDF-260 KB)</span></a></div></div></div></div> <p><strong>There’s never been a better time</strong> to be a behaviorist. During four decades, the academic theory that financial markets accurately reflect a stock’s underlying value was all but unassailable. But lately, the view that investors can fundamentally change a market’s course through irrational decisions has been moving into the mainstream.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>
With the exuberance of the high-tech stock bubble and the crash of the late 1990s still fresh in investors’ memories, adherents of the behaviorist school are finding it easier than ever to spread the belief that markets can be something less than efficient in immediately distilling new information and that investors, driven by emotion, can indeed lead markets awry. Some behaviorists would even assert that stock markets lead lives of their own, detached from economic growth and business profitability. A number of finance scholars and practitioners have argued that stock markets are not efficient—that is, that they don’t necessarily reflect economic fundamentals.<a class="link-footnote" rel="#footnote1" href="#"><sup>1</sup></a> <span id="footnote1" class="tooltip" style="display:none"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">1.</span><span class="footnote-text">
For an overview of behavioral finance, see Jay R. Ritter, “Behavioral finance,” <em>Pacific-Basin Finance Journal</em>, 2003, Volume 11, Number 4, pp. 429–37; and Nicholas Barberis and Richard H. Thaler, “A survey of behavioral finance,” in <em>Handbook of the Economics of Finance: Financial Markets and Asset Pricing</em>, G. M. Constantinides et al. (eds.), New York: Elsevier North-Holland, 2003, pp. 1054–123.</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span> According to this point of view, significant and lasting deviations from the intrinsic value of a company’s share price occur in market valuations.</p>
<p>
The argument is more than academic. In the 1980s the rise of stock market index funds, which now hold some $1 trillion in assets, was caused in large part by the conviction among investors that efficient-market theories were valuable. And current debates in the United States and elsewhere about privatizing Social Security and other retirement systems may hinge on assumptions about how investors are likely to handle their retirement options.</p>
<p>
We agree that behavioral finance offers some valuable insights—chief among them the idea that markets are not always right, since rational investors can’t always correct for mispricing by irrational ones. But for managers, the critical question is how often these deviations arise and whether they are so frequent and significant that they should affect the process of financial decision making. In fact, significant deviations from intrinsic value are rare, and markets usually revert rapidly to share prices commensurate with economic fundamentals. Therefore, managers should continue to use the tried-and-true analysis of a company’s discounted cash flow to make their valuation decisions.</p>
<h2>When markets deviate</h2>
<p>
Behavioral-finance theory holds that markets might fail to reflect economic fundamentals under three conditions. When all three apply, the theory predicts that pricing biases in financial markets can be both significant and persistent.</p>
<p><em>Irrational behavior.</em> Investors behave irrationally when they don’t correctly process all the available information while forming their expectations of a company’s future performance. Some investors, for example, attach too much importance to recent events and results, an error that leads them to overprice companies with strong recent performance. Others are excessively conservative and underprice stocks of companies that have released positive news.</p>
<p><em>Systematic patterns of behavior.</em> Even if individual investors decided to buy or sell without consulting economic fundamentals, the impact on share prices would still be limited. Only when their irrational behavior is also systematic (that is, when large groups of investors share particular patterns of behavior) should persistent price deviations occur. Hence behavioral-finance theory argues that patterns of overconfidence, overreaction, and overrepresentation are common to many investors and that such groups can be large enough to prevent a company’s share price from reflecting underlying economic fundamentals—at least for some stocks, some of the time.</p>
<p><em>Limits to arbitrage in financial markets.</em> When investors assume that a company’s recent strong performance alone is an indication of future performance, they may start bidding for shares and drive up the price. Some investors might expect a company that surprises the market in one quarter to go on exceeding expectations. As long as enough other investors notice this myopic overpricing and respond by taking short positions, the share price will fall in line with its underlying indicators.</p>
<p>
This sort of arbitrage doesn’t always occur, however. In practice, the costs, complexity, and risks involved in setting up a short position can be too high for individual investors. If, for example, the share price doesn’t return to its fundamental value while they can still hold on to a short position—the so-called noise-trader risk—they may have to sell their holdings at a loss.</p>
<h2>Momentum and other matters</h2>
<p>
Two well-known patterns of stock market deviations have received considerable attention in academic studies during the past decade: long-term reversals in share prices and short-term momentum.</p>
<p>
First, consider the phenomenon of reversal—high-performing stocks of the past few years typically become low-performing stocks of the next few. Behavioral finance argues that this effect is caused by an overreaction on the part of investors: when they put too much weight on a company’s recent performance, the share price becomes inflated. As additional information becomes available, investors adjust their expectations and a reversal occurs. The same behavior could explain low returns after an initial public offering (IPO), seasoned offerings, a new listing, and so on. Presumably, such companies had a history of strong performance, which was why they went public in the first place. </p>
<p>
Momentum, on the other hand, occurs when positive returns for stocks over the past few months are followed by several more months of positive returns. Behavioral-finance theory suggests that this trend results from systematic underreaction: overconservative investors underestimate the true impact of earnings, divestitures, and share repurchases, for example, so stock prices don’t instantaneously react to good or bad news.</p>
<p>
But academics are still debating whether irrational investors alone can be blamed for the long-term-reversal and short-term-momentum patterns in returns. Some believe that long-term reversals result merely from incorrect measurements of a stock’s risk premium, because investors ignore the risks associated with a company’s size and market-to-capital ratio.<a class="link-footnote" rel="#footnote2" href="#"><sup>2</sup></a> <span id="footnote2" class="tooltip" style="display:none"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">2.</span><span class="footnote-text">
Eugene F. Fama and Kenneth R. French, “Multifactor explanations of asset pricing anomalies,” <em>Journal of Finance</em>, 1996, Volume 51, Number 1, pp. 55–84.</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span> These statistics could be a proxy for liquidity and distress risk. </p>
<p>
Similarly, irrational investors don’t necessarily drive short-term momentum in share price returns. Profits from these patterns are relatively limited after transaction costs have been deducted. Thus, small momentum biases could exist even if all investors were rational.</p>
<p>
Furthermore, behavioral finance still cannot explain why investors overreact under some conditions (such as IPOs) and underreact in others (such as earnings announcements). Since there is no systematic way to predict how markets will respond, some have concluded that this is a further indication of their accuracy.<a class="link-footnote" rel="#footnote3" href="#"><sup>3</sup></a> <span id="footnote3" class="tooltip" style="display:none"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">3.</span><span class="footnote-text">Eugene F. Fama, “Market efficiency, long-term returns, and behavioral finance,” <em>Journal of Financial Economics</em>, 1998, Volume 49, Number 3, pp. 283–306.</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></p>
<h2>Persistent mispricing in carve-outs and dual-listed companies</h2>
<p>
Two well-documented types of market deviation—the mispricing of carve-outs and of dual-listed companies—are used to support behavioral-finance theory. The classic example is the pricing of 3Com and Palm after the latter’s carve-out in March 2000.</p>
<p>
In anticipation of a full spin-off within nine months, 3Com floated 5 percent of its Palm subsidiary. Almost immediately, Palm’s market capitalization was higher than the entire market value of 3Com, implying that 3Com’s other businesses had a negative value. Given the size and profitability of the rest of 3Com’s businesses, this result would clearly indicate mispricing. Why did rational investors fail to exploit the anomaly by going short on Palm’s shares and long on 3Com’s? The reason was that the number of available Palm shares was extremely small after the carve-out: 3Com still held 95 percent of them. As a result, it was extremely difficult to establish a short position, which would have required borrowing shares from a Palm shareholder.</p>
<p>
During the months following the carve-out, the mispricing gradually became less pronounced as the supply of shares through short sales increased steadily. Yet while many investors and analysts knew about the price difference, it persisted for two months—until the Internal Revenue Service formally approved the carve-out’s tax-free status in early May 2002. At that point, a significant part of the uncertainty around the spin-off was removed and the price discrepancy disappeared. This correction suggests that at least part of the mispricing was caused by the risk that the spin-off wouldn’t occur.</p>
<p>
Additional cases of mispricing between parent companies and their carved-out subsidiaries are well documented.<a class="link-footnote" rel="#footnote4" href="#"><sup>4</sup></a> <span id="footnote4" class="tooltip" style="display:none"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">4.</span><span class="footnote-text">
Owen A. Lamont and Richard H. Thaler, “Can the market add and subtract? Mispricing in tech stock carve-outs,” <em>Journal of Political Economy</em>, 2003, Volume 111, Number 2, pp. 227–68; and Mark L. Mitchell, Todd C. Pulvino, and Erik Stafford, “Limited arbitrage in equity markets,” <em>Journal of Finance</em>, 2002, Volume 57, Number 2, pp. 551–84.</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span> In general, these cases involve difficulties setting up short positions to exploit the price differences, which persist until the spin-off takes place or is abandoned. In all cases, the mispricing was corrected within several months.</p>
<p>
A second classic example of investors deviating from fundamentals is the price disparity between the shares of the same company traded on two different exchanges. Consider the case of Royal Dutch Petroleum and “Shell” Transport and Trading, which are traded on the Amsterdam and London stock markets, respectively. Since these twin shares are entitled to a fixed 60–40 portion of the dividends of Royal Dutch/Shell, you would expect their share prices to remain in this fixed ratio.</p>
<p>
Over long periods, however, they have not. In fact, prolonged periods of mispricing can be found for several similar twin-share structures, such as Unilever (Exhibit 1). This phenomenon occurs because large groups of investors prefer (and are prepared to pay a premium for) one of the twin shares. Rational investors typically do not take positions to exploit the opportunity for arbitrage.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Price disparity in twin shares</div></h5></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/strategy%20and%20corporate%20finance/our%20insights/do%20fundamentalsor%20emotionsdrive%20the%20stock%20market/svgz%20028_do_fundamentals_or_emotions_drive_the_stock_market_exh_1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Exhibit" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/strategy%20and%20corporate%20finance/our%20insights/do%20fundamentalsor%20emotionsdrive%20the%20stock%20market/svgz%20028_do_fundamentals_or_emotions_drive_the_stock_market_exh_1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>
Thus in the case of Royal Dutch/Shell, a price differential of as much as 30 percent has persisted at times. Why? The opportunity to arbitrage dual-listed stocks is actually quite unpredictable and potentially costly. Because of noise-trader risk, even a large gap between share prices is no guarantee that those prices will converge in the near term.</p>
<p>
Does this indict the market for mispricing? We don’t think so. In recent years, the price differences for Royal Dutch/Shell and other twin-share stocks have all become smaller. Furthermore, some of these share structures (and price differences) disappeared because the corporations formally merged, a development that underlines the significance of noise-trader risk: as soon as a formal date was set for definitive price convergence, arbitrageurs stepped in to correct any discrepancy. This pattern provides additional evidence that mispricing occurs only under special circumstances—and is by no means a common or long-lasting phenomenon.</p>
<h2>Markets and fundamentals: The bubble of the 1990s</h2>
<p>
Do markets reflect economic fundamentals? We believe so. Long-term returns on capital and growth have been remarkably consistent for the past 35 years, in spite of some deep recessions and periods of very strong economic growth. The median return on equity for all US companies has been a very stable 12 to 15 percent, and long-term GDP growth for the US economy in real terms has been about 3 percent a year since 1945.<a class="link-footnote" rel="#footnote5" href="#"><sup>5</sup></a> <span id="footnote5" class="tooltip" style="display:none"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">5.</span><span class="footnote-text">
US corporate earnings as a percentage of GDP have been remarkably constant over the past 35 years, at around 6 percent.</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span> We also estimate that the inflation-adjusted cost of equity since 1965 has been fairly stable, at about 7 percent.<a class="link-footnote" rel="#footnote6" href="#"><sup>6</sup></a> <span id="footnote6" class="tooltip" style="display:none"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">6.</span><span class="footnote-text">
Marc H. Goedhart, Timothy M. Koller, and Zane D. Williams, “<a href="http://mckstaging.mckinsey.com/Insights/corporate_finance/the_real_cost_of_equity">The real cost of equity</a>,” <em>McKinsey on Finance</em>, Number 5, Autumn 2002, pp. 11–5.</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span></p>
<p>
We used this information to estimate the intrinsic P/E ratios for the US and UK stock markets and then compared them with the actual values.<a class="link-footnote" rel="#footnote7" href="#"><sup>7</sup></a> <span id="footnote7" class="tooltip" style="display:none"><span class="footnote-content"><span class="footnote-number">7.</span><span class="footnote-text">
Marc H. Goedhart, Timothy M. Koller, and Zane D. Williams, “<a href="http://mckstaging.mckinsey.com/Insights/corporate_finance/living_with_lower_market_expectations">Living with lower market expectations</a>,” <em>McKinsey on Finance</em>, Number 8, Summer 2003, pp. 7–11.</span><span class="clear"></span> </span><span class="footnote-bottom"></span></span> This analysis has led us to three important conclusions. The first is that US and UK stock markets, by and large, have been fairly priced, hovering near their intrinsic P/E ratios. This figure was typically around 15, with the exception of the high-inflation years of the late 1970s and early 1980s, when it was closer to 10 (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Returning to intrinsic valuation</div></h5></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/strategy%20and%20corporate%20finance/our%20insights/do%20fundamentalsor%20emotionsdrive%20the%20stock%20market/svgz%20028_do_fundamentals_or_emotions_drive_the_stock_market_exh_2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Exhibit" src="/~/media/mckinsey/business%20functions/strategy%20and%20corporate%20finance/our%20insights/do%20fundamentalsor%20emotionsdrive%20the%20stock%20market/svgz%20028_do_fundamentals_or_emotions_drive_the_stock_market_exh_2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>
Second, the late 1970s and late 1990s produced significant deviations from intrinsic valuations. In the late 1970s, when investors were obsessed with high short-term inflation rates, the market was probably undervalued; long-term real GDP growth and returns on equity indicate that it shouldn’t have bottomed out at P/E levels of around 7. The other well-known deviation occurred in the late 1990s, when the market reached a P/E ratio of around 30—a level that couldn’t be justified by 3 percent long-term real GDP growth or by 13 percent returns on book equity.</p>
<p>
Third, when such deviations occurred, the stock market returned to its intrinsic-valuation level within about three years. Thus, although valuations have been wrong from time to time—even for the stock market as a whole—eventually they have fallen back in line with economic fundamentals.</p>
<h2>Focus on intrinsic value</h2>
<p>
What are the implications for corporate managers? Paradoxically, we believe that such market deviations make it even more important for the executives of a company to understand the intrinsic value of its shares. This knowledge allows it to exploit any deviations, if and when they occur, to time the implementation of strategic decisions more successfully. Here are some examples of how corporate managers can take advantage of market deviations.</p>
<ul class="leftContentUL">
    <li>
    <p>Issuing additional share capital when the stock market attaches too high a value to the company’s shares relative to their intrinsic value</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p>Repurchasing shares when the market underprices them relative to their intrinsic value</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p>Paying for acquisitions with shares instead of cash when the market overprices them relative to their intrinsic value </p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p>Divesting particular businesses at times when trading and transaction multiples are higher than can be justified by underlying fundamentals</p>
    </li>
</ul>
<p>
Bear two things in mind. First, we don’t recommend that companies base decisions to issue or repurchase their shares, to divest or acquire businesses, or to settle transactions with cash or shares solely on an assumed difference between the market and intrinsic value of their shares. Instead, these decisions must be grounded in a strong business strategy driven by the goal of creating shareholder value. Market deviations are more relevant as tactical considerations when companies time and execute such decisions—for example, when to issue additional capital or how to pay for a particular transaction.</p>
<p>
Second, managers should be wary of analyses claiming to highlight market deviations. Most of the alleged cases that we have come across in our client experience proved to be insignificant or even nonexistent, so the evidence should be compelling. Furthermore, the deviations should be significant in both size and duration, given the capital and time needed to take advantage of the types of opportunities listed previously.</p>
<hr>
<p>
Provided that a company’s share price eventually returns to its intrinsic value in the long run, managers would benefit from using a discounted-cash-flow approach for strategic decisions. What should matter is the long-term behavior of the share price of a company, not whether it is undervalued by 5 or 10 percent at any given time. For strategic business decisions, the evidence strongly suggests that the market reflects intrinsic value. </p>

<i>McKinsey Quarterly</i></span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Do fundamentalsor emotionsdrive the stock market","displayName":"Do fundamentalsor emotionsdrive the stock market","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"f64cf319-5b18-4559-9fac-cd18e2d09cc5","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Do fundamentals—or emotions—drive the stock market?"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Emotions can drive market behavior in a few short-lived situations. But fundamentals still rule."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2005-03-01T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]] \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s never been a better time\u003c/strong\u003e to be a behaviorist. During four decades, the academic theory that financial markets accurately reflect a stock\u0026rsquo;s underlying value was all but unassailable. But lately, the view that investors can fundamentally change a market\u0026rsquo;s course through irrational decisions has been moving into the mainstream.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[audio Fundamentals]]\n\u003cp\u003e\nWith the exuberance of the high-tech stock bubble and the crash of the late 1990s still fresh in investors\u0026rsquo; memories, adherents of the behaviorist school are finding it easier than ever to spread the belief that markets can be something less than efficient in immediately distilling new information and that investors, driven by emotion, can indeed lead markets awry. Some behaviorists would even assert that stock markets lead lives of their own, detached from economic growth and business profitability. A number of finance scholars and practitioners have argued that stock markets are not efficient\u0026mdash;that is, that they don\u0026rsquo;t necessarily reflect economic fundamentals.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote1\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e1\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote1\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e1.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nFor an overview of behavioral finance, see Jay R. Ritter, \u0026ldquo;Behavioral finance,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003ePacific-Basin Finance Journal\u003c/em\u003e, 2003, Volume 11, Number 4, pp. 429\u0026ndash;37; and Nicholas Barberis and Richard H. Thaler, \u0026ldquo;A survey of behavioral finance,\u0026rdquo; in \u003cem\u003eHandbook of the Economics of Finance: Financial Markets and Asset Pricing\u003c/em\u003e, G. M. Constantinides et al. (eds.), New York: Elsevier North-Holland, 2003, pp. 1054\u0026ndash;123.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e According to this point of view, significant and lasting deviations from the intrinsic value of a company\u0026rsquo;s share price occur in market valuations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThe argument is more than academic. In the 1980s the rise of stock market index funds, which now hold some $1 trillion in assets, was caused in large part by the conviction among investors that efficient-market theories were valuable. And current debates in the United States and elsewhere about privatizing Social Security and other retirement systems may hinge on assumptions about how investors are likely to handle their retirement options.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nWe agree that behavioral finance offers some valuable insights\u0026mdash;chief among them the idea that markets are not always right, since rational investors can\u0026rsquo;t always correct for mispricing by irrational ones. But for managers, the critical question is how often these deviations arise and whether they are so frequent and significant that they should affect the process of financial decision making. In fact, significant deviations from intrinsic value are rare, and markets usually revert rapidly to share prices commensurate with economic fundamentals. Therefore, managers should continue to use the tried-and-true analysis of a company\u0026rsquo;s discounted cash flow to make their valuation decisions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhen markets deviate\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nBehavioral-finance theory holds that markets might fail to reflect economic fundamentals under three conditions. When all three apply, the theory predicts that pricing biases in financial markets can be both significant and persistent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIrrational behavior.\u003c/em\u003e Investors behave irrationally when they don\u0026rsquo;t correctly process all the available information while forming their expectations of a company\u0026rsquo;s future performance. Some investors, for example, attach too much importance to recent events and results, an error that leads them to overprice companies with strong recent performance. Others are excessively conservative and underprice stocks of companies that have released positive news.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSystematic patterns of behavior.\u003c/em\u003e Even if individual investors decided to buy or sell without consulting economic fundamentals, the impact on share prices would still be limited. Only when their irrational behavior is also systematic (that is, when large groups of investors share particular patterns of behavior) should persistent price deviations occur. Hence behavioral-finance theory argues that patterns of overconfidence, overreaction, and overrepresentation are common to many investors and that such groups can be large enough to prevent a company\u0026rsquo;s share price from reflecting underlying economic fundamentals\u0026mdash;at least for some stocks, some of the time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLimits to arbitrage in financial markets.\u003c/em\u003e When investors assume that a company\u0026rsquo;s recent strong performance alone is an indication of future performance, they may start bidding for shares and drive up the price. Some investors might expect a company that surprises the market in one quarter to go on exceeding expectations. As long as enough other investors notice this myopic overpricing and respond by taking short positions, the share price will fall in line with its underlying indicators.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThis sort of arbitrage doesn\u0026rsquo;t always occur, however. In practice, the costs, complexity, and risks involved in setting up a short position can be too high for individual investors. If, for example, the share price doesn\u0026rsquo;t return to its fundamental value while they can still hold on to a short position\u0026mdash;the so-called noise-trader risk\u0026mdash;they may have to sell their holdings at a loss.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMomentum and other matters\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nTwo well-known patterns of stock market deviations have received considerable attention in academic studies during the past decade: long-term reversals in share prices and short-term momentum.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nFirst, consider the phenomenon of reversal\u0026mdash;high-performing stocks of the past few years typically become low-performing stocks of the next few. Behavioral finance argues that this effect is caused by an overreaction on the part of investors: when they put too much weight on a company\u0026rsquo;s recent performance, the share price becomes inflated. As additional information becomes available, investors adjust their expectations and a reversal occurs. The same behavior could explain low returns after an initial public offering (IPO), seasoned offerings, a new listing, and so on. Presumably, such companies had a history of strong performance, which was why they went public in the first place. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nMomentum, on the other hand, occurs when positive returns for stocks over the past few months are followed by several more months of positive returns. Behavioral-finance theory suggests that this trend results from systematic underreaction: overconservative investors underestimate the true impact of earnings, divestitures, and share repurchases, for example, so stock prices don\u0026rsquo;t instantaneously react to good or bad news.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nBut academics are still debating whether irrational investors alone can be blamed for the long-term-reversal and short-term-momentum patterns in returns. Some believe that long-term reversals result merely from incorrect measurements of a stock\u0026rsquo;s risk premium, because investors ignore the risks associated with a company\u0026rsquo;s size and market-to-capital ratio.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote2\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e2\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote2\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e2.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nEugene F. Fama and Kenneth R. French, \u0026ldquo;Multifactor explanations of asset pricing anomalies,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eJournal of Finance\u003c/em\u003e, 1996, Volume 51, Number 1, pp. 55\u0026ndash;84.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e These statistics could be a proxy for liquidity and distress risk. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nSimilarly, irrational investors don\u0026rsquo;t necessarily drive short-term momentum in share price returns. Profits from these patterns are relatively limited after transaction costs have been deducted. Thus, small momentum biases could exist even if all investors were rational.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nFurthermore, behavioral finance still cannot explain why investors overreact under some conditions (such as IPOs) and underreact in others (such as earnings announcements). Since there is no systematic way to predict how markets will respond, some have concluded that this is a further indication of their accuracy.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote3\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e3\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote3\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e3.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eEugene F. Fama, \u0026ldquo;Market efficiency, long-term returns, and behavioral finance,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eJournal of Financial Economics\u003c/em\u003e, 1998, Volume 49, Number 3, pp. 283\u0026ndash;306.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePersistent mispricing in carve-outs and dual-listed companies\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nTwo well-documented types of market deviation\u0026mdash;the mispricing of carve-outs and of dual-listed companies\u0026mdash;are used to support behavioral-finance theory. The classic example is the pricing of 3Com and Palm after the latter\u0026rsquo;s carve-out in March 2000.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nIn anticipation of a full spin-off within nine months, 3Com floated 5 percent of its Palm subsidiary. Almost immediately, Palm\u0026rsquo;s market capitalization was higher than the entire market value of 3Com, implying that 3Com\u0026rsquo;s other businesses had a negative value. Given the size and profitability of the rest of 3Com\u0026rsquo;s businesses, this result would clearly indicate mispricing. Why did rational investors fail to exploit the anomaly by going short on Palm\u0026rsquo;s shares and long on 3Com\u0026rsquo;s? The reason was that the number of available Palm shares was extremely small after the carve-out: 3Com still held 95 percent of them. As a result, it was extremely difficult to establish a short position, which would have required borrowing shares from a Palm shareholder.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nDuring the months following the carve-out, the mispricing gradually became less pronounced as the supply of shares through short sales increased steadily. Yet while many investors and analysts knew about the price difference, it persisted for two months\u0026mdash;until the Internal Revenue Service formally approved the carve-out\u0026rsquo;s tax-free status in early May 2002. At that point, a significant part of the uncertainty around the spin-off was removed and the price discrepancy disappeared. This correction suggests that at least part of the mispricing was caused by the risk that the spin-off wouldn\u0026rsquo;t occur.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nAdditional cases of mispricing between parent companies and their carved-out subsidiaries are well documented.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote4\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e4\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote4\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e4.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nOwen A. Lamont and Richard H. Thaler, \u0026ldquo;Can the market add and subtract? Mispricing in tech stock carve-outs,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eJournal of Political Economy\u003c/em\u003e, 2003, Volume 111, Number 2, pp. 227\u0026ndash;68; and Mark L. Mitchell, Todd C. Pulvino, and Erik Stafford, \u0026ldquo;Limited arbitrage in equity markets,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eJournal of Finance\u003c/em\u003e, 2002, Volume 57, Number 2, pp. 551\u0026ndash;84.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e In general, these cases involve difficulties setting up short positions to exploit the price differences, which persist until the spin-off takes place or is abandoned. In all cases, the mispricing was corrected within several months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nA second classic example of investors deviating from fundamentals is the price disparity between the shares of the same company traded on two different exchanges. Consider the case of Royal Dutch Petroleum and \u0026ldquo;Shell\u0026rdquo; Transport and Trading, which are traded on the Amsterdam and London stock markets, respectively. Since these twin shares are entitled to a fixed 60\u0026ndash;40 portion of the dividends of Royal Dutch/Shell, you would expect their share prices to remain in this fixed ratio.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nOver long periods, however, they have not. In fact, prolonged periods of mispricing can be found for several similar twin-share structures, such as Unilever (Exhibit 1). This phenomenon occurs because large groups of investors prefer (and are prepared to pay a premium for) one of the twin shares. Rational investors typically do not take positions to exploit the opportunity for arbitrage.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\nThus in the case of Royal Dutch/Shell, a price differential of as much as 30 percent has persisted at times. Why? The opportunity to arbitrage dual-listed stocks is actually quite unpredictable and potentially costly. Because of noise-trader risk, even a large gap between share prices is no guarantee that those prices will converge in the near term.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nDoes this indict the market for mispricing? We don\u0026rsquo;t think so. In recent years, the price differences for Royal Dutch/Shell and other twin-share stocks have all become smaller. Furthermore, some of these share structures (and price differences) disappeared because the corporations formally merged, a development that underlines the significance of noise-trader risk: as soon as a formal date was set for definitive price convergence, arbitrageurs stepped in to correct any discrepancy. This pattern provides additional evidence that mispricing occurs only under special circumstances\u0026mdash;and is by no means a common or long-lasting phenomenon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eMarkets and fundamentals: The bubble of the 1990s\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nDo markets reflect economic fundamentals? We believe so. Long-term returns on capital and growth have been remarkably consistent for the past 35 years, in spite of some deep recessions and periods of very strong economic growth. The median return on equity for all US companies has been a very stable 12 to 15 percent, and long-term GDP growth for the US economy in real terms has been about 3 percent a year since 1945.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote5\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e5\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote5\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e5.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nUS corporate earnings as a percentage of GDP have been remarkably constant over the past 35 years, at around 6 percent.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e We also estimate that the inflation-adjusted cost of equity since 1965 has been fairly stable, at about 7 percent.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote6\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e6\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote6\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e6.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nMarc H. Goedhart, Timothy M. Koller, and Zane D. Williams, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"http://mckstaging.mckinsey.com/Insights/corporate_finance/the_real_cost_of_equity\"\u003eThe real cost of equity\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eMcKinsey on Finance\u003c/em\u003e, Number 5, Autumn 2002, pp. 11\u0026ndash;5.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nWe used this information to estimate the intrinsic P/E ratios for the US and UK stock markets and then compared them with the actual values.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote7\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e7\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote7\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e7.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nMarc H. Goedhart, Timothy M. Koller, and Zane D. Williams, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"http://mckstaging.mckinsey.com/Insights/corporate_finance/living_with_lower_market_expectations\"\u003eLiving with lower market expectations\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eMcKinsey on Finance\u003c/em\u003e, Number 8, Summer 2003, pp. 7\u0026ndash;11.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e This analysis has led us to three important conclusions. The first is that US and UK stock markets, by and large, have been fairly priced, hovering near their intrinsic P/E ratios. This figure was typically around 15, with the exception of the high-inflation years of the late 1970s and early 1980s, when it was closer to 10 (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\nSecond, the late 1970s and late 1990s produced significant deviations from intrinsic valuations. In the late 1970s, when investors were obsessed with high short-term inflation rates, the market was probably undervalued; long-term real GDP growth and returns on equity indicate that it shouldn\u0026rsquo;t have bottomed out at P/E levels of around 7. The other well-known deviation occurred in the late 1990s, when the market reached a P/E ratio of around 30\u0026mdash;a level that couldn\u0026rsquo;t be justified by 3 percent long-term real GDP growth or by 13 percent returns on book equity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThird, when such deviations occurred, the stock market returned to its intrinsic-valuation level within about three years. Thus, although valuations have been wrong from time to time\u0026mdash;even for the stock market as a whole\u0026mdash;eventually they have fallen back in line with economic fundamentals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFocus on intrinsic value\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nWhat are the implications for corporate managers? Paradoxically, we believe that such market deviations make it even more important for the executives of a company to understand the intrinsic value of its shares. This knowledge allows it to exploit any deviations, if and when they occur, to time the implementation of strategic decisions more successfully. Here are some examples of how corporate managers can take advantage of market deviations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul class=\"leftContentUL\"\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eIssuing additional share capital when the stock market attaches too high a value to the company\u0026rsquo;s shares relative to their intrinsic value\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eRepurchasing shares when the market underprices them relative to their intrinsic value\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003ePaying for acquisitions with shares instead of cash when the market overprices them relative to their intrinsic value \u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eDivesting particular businesses at times when trading and transaction multiples are higher than can be justified by underlying fundamentals\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nBear two things in mind. First, we don\u0026rsquo;t recommend that companies base decisions to issue or repurchase their shares, to divest or acquire businesses, or to settle transactions with cash or shares solely on an assumed difference between the market and intrinsic value of their shares. Instead, these decisions must be grounded in a strong business strategy driven by the goal of creating shareholder value. Market deviations are more relevant as tactical considerations when companies time and execute such decisions\u0026mdash;for example, when to issue additional capital or how to pay for a particular transaction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nSecond, managers should be wary of analyses claiming to highlight market deviations. Most of the alleged cases that we have come across in our client experience proved to be insignificant or even nonexistent, so the evidence should be compelling. Furthermore, the deviations should be significant in both size and duration, given the capital and time needed to take advantage of the types of opportunities listed previously.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nProvided that a company\u0026rsquo;s share price eventually returns to its intrinsic value in the long run, managers would benefit from using a discounted-cash-flow approach for strategic decisions. What should matter is the long-term behavior of the share price of a company, not whether it is undervalued by 5 or 10 percent at any given time. For strategic business decisions, the evidence strongly suggests that the market reflects intrinsic value. \u003c/p\u003e\n"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Book Excerpt"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":{"name":"McKinsey Quarterly","displayName":"McKinsey Quarterly","title":{"value":"McKinsey Quarterly"},"relatedlinks":{"url":"/quarterly/overview"},"landinglinks":{"jsonValue":{"value":[]}}}},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2005-03-01T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"contributoryPractice":{"targetItems":[]},"aboutTheAuthors":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMarc Goedhart\u003c/strong\u003e is an associate principal in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Amsterdam office, and \u003cstrong\u003eTim Koller\u003c/strong\u003e is a principal in the New York office. \u003cstrong\u003eDavid Wessels\u003c/strong\u003e, an alumnus of the New York office, is an adjunct professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.
